titleStmt.title: The Swan Tripe-Club:
A Satyr on the High-Flyers in

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Ecce iterum Crispinus!---- Juv: Sat:4.
Imaginary Dangers they Create,
And Loath the Elixir that preserv'd the State.
Garth's Dispens:
How this Fantastick World is chang'd of late!
Sure some full Moon has Work'd upon the state:
Time was when it was Question'd much in story,
Which best deserv'd, The Devil or a Tory?
But now alass! those happy times are O're,
The Rampant Things are Couchant now no more,
But Trump up Torys, who were Whigs before.There was a time when fair Britannia Lay
Dissolv'd in Ease, and with a gentle sway
Enjoy'd the Blessings of an Halcyon day!
Pleas'd with the Bliss, their friendly Union made,
Beneath the bending Olive's peacefull shade,
Careless and free her happy Sons were laid.
No feuds, no groundless Jealousys appear
To Rouze their Rage, or Wake them into Fear:
With pity they beheld a Neighb'ring State,
Tost by the Tempest of a Stormy Fate;
Wild Frenzy thro' her blasted Borders past,
Whilst Noisy Faction drove the furious Blast;
Calm and serene We heard the Tempest Roar
And fearless View'd the Danger from the Shore.Thus blest, We slumber'd in a downy Trance
Happy like Eden in mild Ignorance;
'Till Discord, like the Wiley Serpent, found
Th' unguarded Path to the forbidden Ground.
Shew'd us the Tree, ye tempting Tree which stood
The fairest, but most fatal of the Wood;
And Where (as hanging on the Golden Bough)
The glittering Fruit Look'd smiling to the View.
Taste, and be Wise, the sly Provoker said
And see the Platform of Your Ruin laid:
Rouze from the Dullness You too long have shown,
And View your Church's Danger, and Yṛ own.
Thus at superior Wit we catch'd in hast
Which mock'd th' Approach of Our deluded Tast.
And, now───────
Imaginary Schemes we seem to spy,
And search for dangers with a curious Eye;
From Thought to thought we roul, and rack our sense,
To Obviate Mischiefs in the Future Tense:
Strange Plots in Embryo, from the Lords We fear,
And dream of mighty Ills, the Lord knows Where;
Wretchedly Wise, We curse our present store,
And bless the Wittles Age We knew before.Near that Fam'd 1Lucas's Coffee house Place, where slender Wights resort,
And gay Pulvilio keeps his scented Court;
Where Exil'd Witt ne'er shews its hated Face,
But happyer Nonsence fills the Thoughtless Place;
Where sucking Beaux, our future hopes are bred
The sharping Gamester, and the Bully Red,
O'er-stock'd with Fame, but indigent of Bread:There stands a 2Swan Tavern modern Dome, of Vast Renown,
For a Plump Cook and plumper Reck'nings known:
Rais'd high, the Fair Jnviting Bird You see
In all his milky Plumes, and feather'd Letchery:
In whose soft down Immortall Jove was drest,
When the fair Nymph the Wilely God possest:
Still in which shape He stands to Mortal View,
Patron of Whoreing and of Topeing too.
Here gravely meet the Worthy sons of Zeal
To Wett their pious Clay, and decently to Rail.
Immortal Courage from the Claret springs,
To Censure Heroes, and the Acts of Kings:
Young Doctors of the Gown here shrewdly show
How Grace Divine can Ebb, and spleen can flow;
The Pious Red-Coat most devoutly swears,
Drinks to the Church, but Ticks on his Arrears;
The gentle Beau too Ioins in Wise Debate,
Adjusts his Cravat, and Reforms the State.
As when the sun, on a Returning Flood,
Warms into Life the Animated Mud;
Strange Wondrous Insects on the Shoar remain,
And a new Race of Vermin fills the Plain:
So from the Excrement of Zeal we find,
A slimy Race, but of the Modish kind;
Crawl from the filth, and kindl'd into Man,
Make up the Members of the Sage Divan.Of these the Fam'd 3Doctr.. Higgins. Borachio is the Chief,
A Son of Pudding and Eternal Beef;
The Iovial God, with all inspireing Grace,
Sitts on the Scarlet Honours of his Face;
His happy Face, from rigid Wisdom free
Securely smiles in Thoughtless Majesty,
His own Tith-Geese not half so plump as He.
Wild notions flow from his immoderate Head,
And Statues quoted,──moderately read;
Whole floods of Words his moderate Witt reveal,
Yet the Good Man's immoderate in his Zeal.
How can his fluent Tongue, and Thought keep touch,
Who Thinks too Little, but who Talks too much?
When Peacefull Tarrs With Gallick Navies meet,
And Loose their Honour to preserve the Fleet;
This wondrous Man alone shall Conquest Boast,
And Win the Battles which the Heroes Lost.
When just Esteem he would of William raise,
He damns the Glories, which he means to Praise;
The poor Encomium is so thinly spread,
It shames the injur'd Ashes of the Dead;
Tho for the Orator, 'tis said withall,
He meant to Praise Him if he Meant at all.Egregious 4Arch-Deacon Percival. Magpye charms the Listning Throng,
Whilst inoffensive Satyr tips his Tongue.
Grey Politicks adorn the Beardless Chit,
Of Foreign Manners, but of Native Witt:
Scarce Wain'd from Diddy of his Alma Mater,
The Cocking Thing steps forth the Churches Erra Pater.
High-flying Thoughts his Low-built Size supply,
And Hoist the Towring Puppet to the sky;
On Brazen Wings, Beat out from Native stock
He Mounts, and rides upon the Weather-Cock;
From Whence the stupid British Jsle he views,
The stupid British Jsle he sees, and spews;
Laments the Talent of his Wisdom Lost
Upon an Isle, and a rough Northern Coast.
Thus Daws, when Perch't upon a steeple's top,
With Paris-strut, and Pride superiour hop;
And whilst on Earth, They haughty Glances throw,
Take humble Curats but for Daws below.5 Firedrake, a Senator of Awkard Grace
But fam'd for Matchless Modesty and Face;
With Christian Clamour fills the deafned Room,
And Prophecys of Wondrous Ills to Come.
Heav'n in a hurry seems to've form'd his Paste,
Fill'd up his spleen, but left his Head-piece waste,
He thinks, he Argues, nay he Prays in haste.
When in soil'd sheets the Dirty Wight is spread,
And high-flown Schemes for Curtains grace ye Bed;
Wild freakish Fancy, with her Airy Train,
Whirls thro' the Empty Region of his Brain:
Shews him the Church, just tott'ring on his head,
And all her mangl'd sons around her spread;
Paints out himself, of all his hopes Beguil'd,
And his Domestick Sicorax defil'd:
Then kindling att the sight, he flys about
And putts dissenting Squadrons to the Rout;
Brim full of Wrath, he plunges into strife
And thumps the Passive Carcase of his Wife;
He Routs the Flying Foe, He scours the Plain,
And boldly fights the Visionary scene.Th' Appollo of the Cause Old 6 Grimbeard stands,
And all th'Inferiour Fry of Wit Commands;
Nurst up in Faction, and a Foe to Peace,
He robs his Bones of Necessary ease;
Drunk with inveterate spleen, he scorns his Age,
And Nature's Lowest Ebb supplys wtḥ sprightly Rage.
Cold driveling Time has all his Nerves unstrung,
But left untouch'd his Letchery of Tongue;
His Letchery of Tongue, which still remains,
And adds a friendly Aid to Want of Brains:
He blames the dullness of his Party's sloth,
And Chides the fears of their unactive Youth;
Tells them the Time, the happy Time is come,
When Moderation shall Behold its Doom;
When sniveling Mercy shall no more beguile,
But Christian Force, and Pious Rage shall smile;
Warns them against those dangers to provide,
Those Dangers which his spectacles have spy'd,
Dark and unknown to all the World beside.
Hail, Venerable Man! design'd by Fate
The saving Genius of a sinking State!
Lo, Prostrate att thy Feet We trembling fall
Thou great Twin-Idol of the Thund'ring Baal!
How shall thy Votarys thy Wrath asswage,
Unbend thy Frowns, and deprecate thy Rage?
Millions of Victims shall thy Altars soil,
Heroes shall Bleed, and Treasurers shall Broil:
Thy Divine Worth shall in our Lays be sung
O Bend thy stubborn Rage, and sheath thy dreadful Tongue.7Mr Nuttley Nut-brain, a Daggle Gown of Large Renown,
For weak support to needy Client known;
With painted dangers keeps his Mob in Awe,
And shrewdly construes Faction into Law.
When Popish Councill wav'd its fatall Wand,
And with Hibernian Locusts curst the Land;
Our fruitfull Egypt, with the Load Opprest,
Beheld, with Grief, its happy fields laid waste:
With Watry Eyes, and with a Mother's Pain,
She heard her People groan, but heard in Vain,
Till that bles't Change────And then they took ye Wind,
But left this stragling Vermin here behind:
Too well he lik'd our fruitfull Egypt's Plain,
To hungry Dublin to Return again.Say, Blind Britannia, for what Charms unknown
Y' adopt a Man, whom You should Blush to Own:
Beggar'd, and spoild of all Your Wealthy store,
Yet hug the Viper, whom Yee Curst before.
Is this the pious Champion of Your Cause
Who Robs Your Off-spring to Protect yṛ Laws?
Slily distills his Venom to the Root,
And Blasts the Tree from Whence he plucks ye fruit;
Who sees Your Ruin, which he smiles to see,
Whose Gain's his Heaven, and only God's a Fee?In the first Rank fam'd 8Doctr. Worth Sooterkin is seen
Of happy Visage, and Enchanting Mien,
A Lazy Modish son of Melancholly spleen:
Whose ev'ry feature flourishes in Print,
And early Pride first Taught the Youth to squint.
What niggard Father wou'd begrudge his Brass,
When travell'd son does home-bred Boy surpass?
Went out a fopling and return'd an Ass.
Of thought so dark, that no Erroneous Hit
E'er shew'd the Lucid Beautys of his Wit.
When scanty fee Expects a healing Pill,
With Careless Yawn he nods upon the Bill
Secure to hit;────who never fails to kill.
When Costive Punk in Penitential Case,
Sits squeezing out her soul in Vile Grimace,
To ease his Patient he prescribes────his face.
Well may the Wretch a Providence disown,
Who thinks no Wisdom brighter than his own;
Long since he left Religion in the lurch,
Who Yet wou'd raise the Glorys of the Church,
And stickles for its Rites, who ne'er comes near ye Porch.Immortal Crab stands firmly to the Truth,
And with sage Nod Commands the List'ning Youth;
In Whom rank spleen has all his Vigour shown,
And blended all its Curses into One;
O'erflowing Gall has Chang'd the Crimson Blood
And turn'd to Vinegar the Wretche's Blood.
Nightly on bended knees, the Musty Putt,
Still saints the spigot, and adores the Butt;
With fervent Zeal the flowing Liquor plys,
But Damns the moderate Bottle for its size
His Liquid Vows cut swiftly thro' the Air
When Glorious Red has Whetted him to prayer;
Thrifty of Time, and frugall of his Ways,
Fopling he Rails, and as he rails he Prays.In the sage List, Great 9Arch: Deacon Neile. Moon-Calf is enroll'd,
Fam'd as the Delphick Oracle of Old.
Propitious dullness, and a senseless Joy,
Shone att his Birth, and Blest the hopefull Boy;
Who utters Wonders without sense of Pain,
And scorns the Crabbed Labour of the Brain.
Fleeting as Air his Words out-strip the Wind,
Whilst the sage tardy Meaning laggs behind
No sawcy foresight dares his Will Controul,
Or stop the impetuous Motion of his soul;
His soul, which struggles in her dark Abode,
Crush'd, and o'erlay'd with the unweildy Load.
Prevailing dullness did his sense betray,
And crampt his Reason to Extend his Clay;
His Wit Contracted to a Narrow span,
A Yard of Ideot, to an Inch of Man.
Hail, Mighty Dunce, thou largest of thy kind,
How well thy Mein is suited to thy Mind!
What if the Lords and Commons can't agree,
Thou dear, dull, happy Thing, what is't to Thee?
Sitt down contented with thy present store
Heav'n ne'er design'd thee to be wise and poor;
Trust to thy fate, whatever Partys Joyn,
Thy Want of sense obstructs thy want of Coin.
As when Imperial Rome beheld her state
Grown faint, and strugling with impending Fate;
When Barbarous Nations on her Ruins Trod,
And no kind Jove appear'd her Guardian God;
A sacred Goose could all her fears disperse,
And save the Mistress of the Universe:
Of equall Fame the Great Example be,
Our Church's safety We expect from thee;
In Thee, Great Man, the saving Brood Remains,
Of equal Piety and Equal Brains;
In this We differ but in point of Name
Unlike the Romans We, but Thou, our Goose, the same.And now with solemn Grace the Council sat,
And the Third Flasque had rais'd a Warm Debate;
When Faction Entri'ng Walk'd the Giddy-Maze,
Sworn Foe, and Noted Enemy to Peace;
And Takeing Grimbeard's shape, she silence broke,
And in shrill Voice the Eager Fury spoke.“Be Wittness, Heaven! how much I'm pleas'd to find
“Such Gallant friends, and of so brave a Mind;
“Soul's fitt to Rule the World, and proudly sit
“The Noblest Sons of Piety and Wit.
“Uncommon Vigour in Your Looks I spy,
“Resolv'd the uttmost of Your Force to try;
“Bravely to stickle for Your Church's Laws,
“And shed a gen'rous Influence on her Cause.
“See how with Grief she hangs her pensive head,
“Whilst Trickling Tears upon her Garments shed,
“Mourn all her Lustre and her Beauty fled.
“In Hair disshevel'd, and with Bosome bare
“With Melancholly sounds she fills the Air.
“Wou'd You, my Friends, the weighty Business know,
“And Learn the Cruell Reason of her Woe?
“The Cause she has to Grieve, the World believes
“Is this──Hem──Hem──Why? 'tis enough she Grieves:
“What sons from Tears their Flinty souls can keep,
“And with drye Eys behold their Mother weep?
“Ah! stop the Deluge of her Watry store,
“And lett her taste those Joys she felt before.“When William (Curse upon that hated Name!
“For ever Blotted and unknown to Fame)
“When William in Imperial Glory shone
“And to our Grief possest Britannia's Throne,
“Mark with what Malice He our Church debas'd,
“Her Songs Neglected, and her Rites defac'd:
“To Canting Zeal design'd her Form a slave,
“And meant to Ruin, what He came to save.
“What tho the World be fill'd with his Alarms,
“And fainting Gallia trembl'd at his Arms;
“Yet still the doughty Heroe did no more
“Than Julius once, and Ammon did before.
“Is this the Idol of the People's Love,
“The poor Mock-Puppet of a Ruling Jove?
“Sorrel! We Owe his hasty fate to Thee,
“Thou Lucky Horse; Oh may thy Mem'ry be
“Fragrant to all, as it is sweet to Me!
“Too far, I fear, the Vile Infection's spread,
“Since Anna courts the Party which He Led,
“And Treads the hated footsteps of the Dead.
“If so, what now can We Expect to hear,
“But Black Effects, of those damn'd Ills We fear?
“Your fat Endowments shall be torn away,
“And to Geneva Zeal become an Easy Prey!
“Cold Element shall give Your Guts the Grip's
“And, ah! no more You shall Indulge in Tripes!
“No Sunday Pudding shall adorn the Board,
“Or Burn the Chops of its too eager Lord!
“No gentle Abigail shall Caudles make
“Nor Cook the Jellys for the Chaplain's Back!
“Long-Winded schismaticks shall Rule the Roast,
“And Father Christmas mourn his Revells Lost!
“Rouze then My friends, and all Your Forces joyn,
“And Act with Vigour in Our great Design;
“What! tho' our Danger is not truly great,
“Tis brave t' oppose a Government We hate:
“Poison the Nation with Your jealous Fears,
“And sett the Fools together by the Ears:
“Whilst with Malicious Ioy We calmly sit,
“And smile to see the Triumphs of Our Wit.
“Sound th' Universitys with Nicest Skill,
“Inflame the Beardless Boys, & bend them to yr Will.
“What tho' unmov'd their learned sons have stood,
“Nor sacrific'd to spleen their Country's Good:
“Yet search throughly, and there will be found
“Some Branches tainted, tho' the Trunks are sound.
“Shew but the Lure, which never fails to hitt;
“Approve their Briskness, and Admire their Wit:
“Youth against Flattery has no Defence,
“Fools still are cheated with the Bait of Sense.
“Glean e'en the schools from Letchery and Birch,
“And Teach the Youngsters to defend the Church.
“Tis Fools We want, and of the Largest size,
“'Twou'd spoil our Cause to pratise on ye Wise
“The Wise are Eagles of the sharpest ken,
“And calmly Weigh the Merits and the Men;
“Pierce thro' the Cobweb Veil of Erring sense,
“And know the Truth of Zeal from the Pretence:
“Whilst Fools, like Game-Cooks, are ye slaves of show,
“And never ask a Cause, but fly upon ye Foe.
“Chance only guides them Wandring in the Night,
“When in an Age they stumble on the Right:
“God never gave a Fool the Gift of Sight.He said──with Joy the pleas'd assembly rose;
Well mov'd, they Cry'd, and murmur'd their Applause;
When, Lo! before the Board, Confest in sight,
Stept forth an Heav'nly Guest serenely Bright
No Mortal Beauty cou'd with here Compare,
Or Poet's Fancy form a Maid so fair;
Around her Head Immortal Glorys shine
And her Mild Air Confest the Nymph divine;
Whilst thus She spake────────“Ask not, my frighted son, from whence J came,
“But mark me well, Religion is my name;
“An Angell once, but now a Fury grown
“Too often talk'd of, but too little known;
“Is it for me, My sons, that You Engage,
“And spend the fury of your Idle Rage?
“Tis false, unmanly spleen Your Bosoms Warms,
“And a pretended Zeal Your Fancy Charms.
“Where have I taught You in the sacred Page,
“To Construe Moderation into Rage;
“T' affront the Pow'r from whence Your safety springs
“And poorly spend Your Rage against ye Best of Kings?
“Branded with Infamy, You shun the Light,
“But Court, like Birds obscene the Covert of the Night.
“Is then unlawfull Riot fit to be
“The Great Supporter of My Church and me?
“Think You, weak men, she's of her Foes affraid,
“Or wants th'Assistance of Your feeble Aid?
“When Round her Throne Seraphick Warriors stand,
“And form upon her side a Heav'nly Band?
“When fixt as Fate, her deep Foundation Lies,
“And spreads Where e'er My Anna's Glory flies?
“Think on th'intended Ruins of the Day,
“When to Proud Rome You were design'd a Prey:
“With wonder read those Fatal Times again
“And call to mind the Melancholly scene;
“When down its Rapid stream the Torrent bore,
“Your Country's Laws, and safety was no more;
“Torn from Your Altars, You were forc'd to Roam
“In needy Exile from your Native home.
“'Twas then, My sons, Your Mighty William rose,
“And Bravely fell like Light'ning on Your Foes:
“With Royal Pity He deplor'd Your fate,
“And stood the Atlas of Your sinking state.
“When sacrifice on Idol Altars slain,
“Polluted all the Isle, and dy'd the Plain;
“Rome's Mob of Saints did all Your Temples fill,
“And Consecrated Groves Crown'd ev'ry Hill:
“'Twas then, Josiah Like that He defac'd
“Their Pagan rites, and laid their Altars Wast;
“Drove out their Idols from their Lov'd Abodes,
“And pounded into Dust their Molten Gods.
“Israel's true Lord was to his Rule restor'd,
“Again his Name was heard, and Was again ador'd.“Wondring You saw Your Great Deliv'rer come,
“And while He War'd Abroad You rail'd at home;
“Dreadfully Gay in Arms but scorn'd in Peace
“The useless Buckler of Inglorious Ease:
“O poor and short-liv'd Glory and Renown!
“O false unenvy'd pleasures of a Crown!
“So soon are all thy shining Honours fled,
“Traduc'd while Living, and defam'd when dead!
“Strange fate of Heroes, who like Comets Blaze,
“And with a sudden Light the World Amaze!
“But When with fading Beams they Quit ye skies,
“No more to shine the Wonder of our Eyes;
“Their Glories spent, and all their fiery store,
“We scorn the Omens, which We fear'd before.“My Royal Anna, whom e'ery Virtue Crowns,
“Feels Your ill govern'd Rage, nor scapes Yṛ Frowns:
“Your want of Duty You supply with spight,
“Traduce Her Councils, and Her Heroes slight;
“Lampoon the Mildness of her easy sway,
“And sicken att the Light of her superior Day;
“Poison her sweets of Life with groundless fears,
“And fill her Royall Breast with Anxious Cares.
“What! such a Queen, where Art and Nature join
“To hitt the Copy of a Form Divine;
“Unerring Wisdom purg'd the Dross away,
“And Form'd Your Anna of a Nobler Clay.
“Breathing a soul, in which in Glory shone
“Goodness innate, and Virtue like its own;
“She knows how farr Engageing sweetness Charms,
“And Conquers more by Mildness than by Arms;
“Like Sampson's Riddle in the sacred song
“A springing sweet still flowing from the strong;
“Like her hasty sparkes her slow Resentmṭ dies,
“Her Rigour Lagging but her Mercy flys.
“Hail, Pious Princess! Mightiest of thy Name,
“Tho last Begotten Yet the First in Fame;
“Those Glorious Heroins We in story see
“Were but the fainter Types of Greater Thee;
“Let others take a Lustre from the Throne,
“You shine with Brighter Glories of Your own,
“Add Worth to Worth and dignifye a Crown.
“Oft have I mark'd with what a studious Care,
“My Words You Ponder, and My Laws revere;
“To Thee Great Queen, What Elogies are due,
“Who both Protect the 10Grants to ye Clergy. Flock, and feed ye shepherds too.
“For Which I still preside O'er thy Alarms,
“And add a shining Lustre to thy Arms;
“I form'd the Battle, and I gave the Word,
“And rid with Conquest on Thy Ormond's Sword,
“When Anjou's Fleet Yielding its Indian store
“And at thy sacred feat depos'd the silver Oar.
“I sent the Goddess when Victoria came,
“And Rais'd thy Churchill to Immortal Fame,
“And Hochstet's bloody Field advanc'd the Heroe's Name
“By Me He yett will more Immortall grow,
“When Ramilies, and Audenard shall know,
“His Arms Triumphant still against the Gallick Foe.
“Nor shall thy Triumphs or thy Glories cease
“'Till Rugged War at last shall soften into Peace.“But first You shall (for Your Repose and mine)
“Your sister Realms in Ancient Union Joyn:
“A Work that Heav'n has still reserv'd for You,
“Which nor Your Fathers, Nor Great William's self cou'd do!
“Charles then from Thee his Diadem shall receive
“And shining Pomp which Thou alone canst Give;
“The Gallick Lion Listning at his shore
“Shall fear to Tempt the Brittish dangers more
“But sculk in Desarts Where he us'd to Roar:
“Admiring Worlds before thy Throne shall stand,
“And Willing Nations bend to thy Command;
“And thus in glorious Ease Thou long shalt Bless ye Land.“For You, Y'inveterate Enemies to Peace,
“Whom Kings can ne'er oblige, nor Heav'n can please:
“Who Blindly Zealous into Faction run,
“And make those dangers You'd be Thought to shun;
“For shame the Transports of Your Rage give o'er,
“And let Your Civil Feuds be heard no more;
“To the Wise Conduct of My Anna trust,
“Know Your own Good and to Your selves be just.
“And with Grief You see Your Brother stray,
“Or in a Night of Error Loose his way,
“Direct his Wandring, and Restore the Day.
“To Guide his steps, afford Your Kindest Aid,
“And gently pity whom You can't persuade.
“Leave to Avenging Heav'n his stubborn will,
“For, o! remember He's Your Brother still:
“Let healing Mercy thro' Your Actions shine,
“And Let Your Lives Confess Yṛ Cause Divine.Frowning the Goddess spoke, & strait withdrew,
Scatt'ring Ambrosial Odours as she Flew;
Her Trembling Sons immoderately scarr'd,
Fled from th'uneasy Truths which suddenly they heard.X77-002D
